node.data: Project Gutenberg is an online platform that offers free eBooks, including "A Christmas Carol" Project Gutenberg is an organization that distributes electronic works, including 'A Christmas Carol', without copyright restrictions in the United States Project Gutenberg is a collection of electronic works, most of which are in the public domain in the United States Project Gutenberg is a digital library offering free access to a large collection of electronic works Project Gutenberg is an initiative focused on the free distribution of electronic works in formats readable by a wide variety of computers. It relies on volunteers and donations to maintain its collection and mission.
Charles Dickens is the author of "A Christmas Carol"
Arthur Rackham is the illustrator of "A Christmas Carol"
J. B. Lippincott Company is the original publisher of "A Christmas Carol" in Philadelphia and New York

The country where Project Gutenberg is based and where the eBook is freely available Mentioned in the context of a security that would become irrelevant if there were no days to count by The country where Project Gutenberg operates and distributes electronic works without copyright restrictions The country where most of the Project Gutenberg works are in the public domain and where the copyright laws mentioned apply The United States is the country where the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation operates and complies with charity laws.
A Christmas Carol is a novella by Charles Dickens, first published in 1843, that tells the story of Ebenezer Scrooge's transformation after being visited by ghosts
Suzanne Shell is one of the producers of the Project Gutenberg eBook of "A Christmas Carol"
Janet Blenkinship is one of the producers of the Project Gutenberg eBook of "A Christmas Carol"
The Online Distributed Proofreading Team is a group that helped produce the Project Gutenberg eBook of "A Christmas Carol"
Philadelphia is one of the cities where "A Christmas Carol" was originally published
New York is one of the cities where "A Christmas Carol" was originally published

Bob Cratchit is a character in "A Christmas Carol," the clerk to Ebenezer Scrooge Bob Cratchit is Scrooge's clerk who asks for a day off on Christmas Eve and enjoys sliding on Cornhill Bob Cratchit is Scrooge's clerk who lives in a modest four-roomed house and earns fifteen 'Bob' a week Bob Cratchit is a character who works hard to support his family, earning only fifteen 'Bob' a week. He is the father of the Cratchit family and is described as wearing threadbare clothes and a long comforter. He is also very caring towards his son, Tiny Tim. Bob Cratchit is a member of the Cratchit family who took Tiny Tim beside him at the table and proposed a toast Bob Cratchit is an employee of Scrooge and the father of Tiny Tim Bob Cratchit is a poor man who is the father of Tiny Tim and husband to Mrs. Cratchit Bob Cratchit is an employee of Scrooge, to whom Scrooge plans to send a large turkey as a surprise gift Bob Cratchit is Scrooge's employee who is late to work but receives a raise and assistance from Scrooge Bob Cratchit is an employee of Scrooge who is promised a raise and assistance for his struggling family

Ebenezer Scrooge is the main character in "A Christmas Carol," known for being a grasping, covetous old man Ebenezer Scrooge is a character who is confronted by a ghost and is deeply troubled by the encounter
Ebenezer Scrooge is the main character who wakes up in a dark room and experiences strange events Ebenezer Scrooge is the name on the neglected grave that Scrooge reads
Peter Cratchit is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a son of Bob Cratchit Peter Cratchit is one of Bob Cratchit's children who is considering a job opportunity
Tim Cratchit, also known as Tiny Tim, is a character in "A Christmas Carol," the youngest son of Bob Cratchit and a cripple
Mr. Fezziwig is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a kind-hearted, jovial old merchant

Fred is a character in "A Christmas Carol," the nephew of Ebenezer Scrooge Fred is Scrooge's nephew who invited Scrooge to dinner
Fred is Scrooge's nephew who hosted the game and led the toast to Scrooge Fred is Scrooge's nephew who welcomes him warmly to dinner

The Ghost of Christmas Past is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a phantom showing things past The Ghost of Christmas Past is a spirit that visits Scrooge to show him scenes from his past The Ghost of Christmas Past is a supernatural entity that illuminates Scrooge's memories and interactions The Ghost of Christmas Past is a supernatural entity that shows Scrooge scenes from his past The Spirit that shows Scrooge scenes from his past The Ghost of Christmas Past is one of the spirits that visits Scrooge to show him scenes from his past

The Ghost of Christmas Present is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a spirit of a kind, generous, and hearty nature The Ghost of Christmas Present is a jolly giant who appears to Scrooge, dressed in a green robe bordered with white fur, and surrounded by festive decorations and food The Ghost of Christmas Present is a specific manifestation of the Spirit that appears to Scrooge The Ghost of Christmas Present is the spirit who accompanies Scrooge and blesses Bob Cratchit's house The Ghost of Christmas Present is a spirit who blesses Bob Cratchit's house with the sprinklings of his torch. He is a supernatural entity who spreads joy and blessings. The Ghost of Christmas Present is a supernatural entity that shows Scrooge scenes from the present
The Ghost of Christmas Present is one of the spirits that visits Scrooge to show him the current state of his life and the lives of others The Ghost of Christmas Present is a spirit that showed Scrooge the joy and festivities of Christmas

node.id: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS YET TO COME
node.data: The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come is a character in "A Christmas Carol," an apparition showing the shadows of things which yet may happen The solemn Phantom that shows Scrooge the future The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come is a spirit that shows Scrooge visions of the future The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come is one of the spirits that visits Scrooge to show him the potential future consequences of his actions

The Ghost of Jacob Marley is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a spectre of Scrooge's former partner in business The Ghost of Jacob Marley is the spectral form of Scrooge's former business partner who warns him of the visits by the three spirits

Joe is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a marine-store dealer and receiver of stolen goods Joe is a character who discussed bed-curtains with a woman Joe is an old man who appraises and buys items from others
Mr. Topper is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a bachelor
Dick Wilkins is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a fellow apprentice of Scrooge's Dick Wilkins is a fellow apprentice of Ebenezer, who was very much attached to him
Belle is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a comely matron and an old sweetheart of Scrooge's Belle is the wife of the master of the house and an old acquaintance of Scrooge

Caroline is a character in "A Christmas Carol," the wife of one of Scrooge's debtors Caroline is a woman who feels a mix of hope and relief upon hearing about the death of a merciless creditor Caroline is a character who feels relief at the death of a merciless creditor

Mrs. Cratchit is a character in "A Christmas Carol," the wife of Bob Cratchit Mrs. Cratchit is Bob Cratchit's wife, who is described as being dressed out but poorly Mrs. Cratchit is Bob Cratchit's wife. She is described as being dressed poorly in a twice-turned gown but makes a good show with ribbons. She is responsible for laying the cloth and preparing the meal. Mrs. Cratchit is a member of the Cratchit family who made the gravy and prepared the pudding for the family dinner Mrs. Cratchit is Bob Cratchit's wife who expresses strong negative feelings towards Scrooge Mrs. Cratchit is the wife of Bob Cratchit and mother of Tiny Tim Mrs. Cratchit is Bob's wife who speaks about Peter and Tiny Tim

Belinda Cratchit is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a daughter of Bob Cratchit Belinda Cratchit is the second daughter of Bob and Mrs. Cratchit. She assists her mother in preparing the meal and is described as being brave in ribbons.

Martha Cratchit is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a daughter of Bob Cratchit Martha Cratchit is the eldest daughter of Bob and Mrs. Cratchit. She arrives late due to work and is warmly welcomed by her family. She hides to surprise her father, Bob. Martha Cratchit is a poor apprentice at a milliner's and one of Bob Cratchit's children

Mrs. Dilber is a character in "A Christmas Carol," a laundress Mrs. Dilber is a woman who enters Old Joe's shop with a heavy bundle Mrs. Dilber is a woman who brings items to Joe for appraisal and sale
Fan is a character in "A Christmas Carol," the sister of Scrooge Fan is Scrooge's younger sister who comes to bring him home for Christmas

Mrs. Fezziwig is a character in "A Christmas Carol," the worthy partner of Mr. Fezziwig Mrs. Fezziwig is a character who danced with Old Fezziwig Mrs. Fezziwig is the wife of Old Fezziwig, known for her substantial smile and participation in the Christmas Eve festivities Mrs. Fezziwig is the partner of Mr. Fezziwig, equally lively and skilled in dancing, and participates in the domestic ballMrs. Fezziwig is the partner of Old Fezziwig, equally lively and skilled in dancing, and participates in the domestic ball

node.id: THE FIRST OF THE THREE SPIRITS
node.data: The First of the Three Spirits is the second chapter of "A Christmas Carol," where Scrooge is visited by the Ghost of Christmas Past The First of the Three Spirits is the initial supernatural entity that will visit Scrooge

node.id: THE SECOND OF THE THREE SPIRITS
node.data: The Second of the Three Spirits is the third chapter of "A Christmas Carol," where Scrooge is visited by the Ghost of Christmas Present
The Last of the Spirits is the fourth chapter of "A Christmas Carol," where Scrooge is visited by the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come
The End of It is the fifth and final chapter of "A Christmas Carol," where Scrooge's transformation is complete

Marley's Ghost is an event where Marley's ghost appears The apparition of Marley that appears to Scrooge, causing him great fear and disbelief Marley's Ghost is the apparition of Jacob Marley, who warns Scrooge about his fate and the visits of three spirits Marley's Ghost is a supernatural entity that haunts Scrooge and warns him of future visitations

Old Fezziwig is a character who stood out to dance with Mrs. Fezziwig Fezziwig is an old gentleman who was Scrooge's employer during his apprenticeship Old Fezziwig is a jovial and benevolent gentleman who runs a business and is known for his lively and generous spirit, especially during Christmas Eve celebrations Old Fezziwig is a character who is described as a lively and skilled dancer, hosting a domestic ball and spreading cheer among his guests

Scrooge is a character known for being tight-fisted, squeezing, wrenching, grasping, scraping, clutching, and covetous. He was Marley's business partner and sole executor Scrooge is a miserly, solitary old man who is described as cold and unfeeling, both physically and emotionally. He is known for his disdain for Christmas and human sympathy. Scrooge is a character who is cynical about Christmas and is the uncle of the nephew in the text Scrooge is a character who is known for his miserly and uncharitable nature, particularly during the Christmas season Scrooge is a character who is depicted as a miserly and grumpy individual, known for his disdain towards Christmas and his clerk Scrooge is the main character who is experiencing strange events in his house Scrooge is a character who is skeptical and disbelieving of supernatural occurrences, particularly the ghost of Marley Scrooge is a character who is being visited by ghosts and is warned about his fate Scrooge is the main character who is being visited by the Ghost of Christmas Past Scrooge is a character who is reflecting on his past and experiencing a range of emotions, from joy to sorrow, as he revisits memories of Christmas Scrooge is a character who is reflecting on his past experiences, including interactions with his sister and his schoolmaster Scrooge is a character who reflects on his past, showing a range of emotions from joy to agitation, and interacts with the Ghost Scrooge is a character who is reflecting on his past and is being shown scenes by a ghost Scrooge is a central character who experiences various supernatural events and reflections on his life Scrooge is the main character who is experiencing strange and supernatural events in his room Scrooge is a character who interacts with the Spirit and learns lessons from it Scrooge is a character who interacts with the Spirit and questions him about his actions and intentions Scrooge is a character who shows concern for Tiny Tim's future and speaks with the Ghost Scrooge is a wealthy, stingy, and unfeeling man who is the subject of much discussion and disdain among the Cratchit family Scrooge is a character who is being guided by a Ghost through various scenes of Christmas celebrations Scrooge is a central character who is surprised by the laughter of his nephew and is described as a comical old fellow who is not very pleasant but very rich Scrooge is a character who is known for his dislike of Christmas and his solitary nature Scrooge is a central character who participated in the games and was the subject of the guessing game The main character who is being shown visions by the Spirit Scrooge is the main character who is being guided by the Phantom Scrooge is a character who is observing the scene and is accompanied by the Phantom Scrooge is a man who is horrified by the actions of Joe and the others Scrooge is a character who is observing a dark room and a dead man, feeling anxious and powerless in the presence of a Phantom Scrooge is a character who is being guided by a ghost to witness various scenes Scrooge is a character who interacts with the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come and learns about his future Scrooge is the main character who undergoes a transformation after being visited by spirits Scrooge is the main character who is experiencing a change of heart and generosity during Christmas Day Scrooge is a central character who undergoes a transformation and becomes generous and kind Scrooge is a character who undergoes a significant transformation, becoming generous and kind-hearted, especially towards Bob Cratchit and Tiny Tim

Marley was Scrooge's business partner, who is now dead. He was as dead as a door-nail Marley is Scrooge's former business partner who has been dead for seven years Marley is Scrooge's deceased partner whose face appears on the knocker of Scrooge's door Marley is a deceased individual whose face Scrooge remembers and who seems to haunt Scrooge Marley is the ghost of Scrooge's former business partner, who appears to him dragging chains made of cash-boxes, keys, padlocks, ledgers, deeds, and heavy purses wrought in steel Marley is mentioned as someone associated with Scrooge, possibly a former partner or acquaintance
Tim is a character mentioned in the context of being someone's blood-horse
St. Paul's Churchyard is a location mentioned as a breezy spot
Uncle Scrooge is another reference to Scrooge, who came to dinner
Marley's Funeral is an event that confirmed Marley's death

Scrooge's nephew is a cheerful and warm-hearted individual who tries to spread Christmas cheer, despite Scrooge's negative attitude. Scrooge's nephew is a cheerful and good-humored character who laughs heartily and expresses sympathy for Scrooge despite his ill whims Scrooge's nephew is a cheerful and good-natured character who tries to include Scrooge in Christmas celebrations Scrooge's nephew is the host of the game and the one who led the toast to Scrooge
The counting-house is the office where Scrooge works, characterized by its cold and bleak environment. The counting-house is the place where Scrooge and Jacob Marley conducted their business

Christmas Eve is the day before Christmas, noted in the text as a significant time when Scrooge is busy in his counting-house. Christmas Eve is the day before Christmas, celebrated by Bob Cratchit and mentioned in the context of Scrooge's disdain Christmas Eve is mentioned as the time when Jacob Marley died seven years ago Christmas Eve is the occasion during which Old Fezziwig hosts a lively and generous celebration, including dancing, food, and merriment

The city where Scrooge's counting-house is located, characterized by cold, bleak, and foggy weather. The City is where Scrooge's business friends are located, who would be surprised to see his emotional state A busy city where Scrooge and the Ghost observe the bustling Christmas-time activities The city where Scrooge and the Spirit find themselves The City is where Scrooge and the Phantom find themselves, particularly in the heart of it The city where Scrooge lives and becomes known as a good man
Offices near Scrooge's counting-house, where candles are flaring in the windows due to the dark and foggy weather.

The court outside Scrooge's counting-house, where people are trying to warm themselves in the cold weather. The corner of the court where the labourers are working and people are gathered around a fire
The clerk works for Scrooge and is sympathetic to the nephew's views on Christmas

The nephew is a character who tries to convince Scrooge of the goodness of Christmas and invites him to dine
Fred, who is Scrooge's nephew and welcomes him to dinner
The business partnership between Scrooge and Marley Scrooge and Marley is the counting-house or business where Scrooge works
Two gentlemen who visit Scrooge's office to seek donations for charity

A holiday that Scrooge is cynical about but the nephew finds valuable and good Christmas is a festive season during which people celebrate and make provisions for the poor and destitute Christmas is a recurring event in the text, associated with Scrooge's memories and emotions Christmas is the holiday during which many of the events in the text take place Christmas is the holiday during which the events and reflections take place, symbolizing joy and reflection Christmas is the holiday during which the events and reflections of Scrooge take place Christmas is the holiday during which the events are taking place, and it is central to the appearance of the Ghost of Christmas Present Christmas is the holiday during which the events are taking place, marked by festive activities and decorations Christmas is the holiday being celebrated by the Cratchit family during their dinner Christmas is the holiday being celebrated by various groups of people in the text Christmas is the holiday being discussed, associated with kindness, festivities, and family gatherings Christmas is the holiday being celebrated, which is central to the story and the characters' interactions The holiday during which the events are taking place
Union workhouses are institutions where the poor and destitute are provided with basic necessities in exchange for labor
The Treadmill is a form of punishment and labor used in workhouses
The Poor Law is legislation aimed at providing relief for the poor, often through workhouses
The Lord Mayor is a high-ranking official who oversees the city and has a household that celebrates Christmas in a grand manner
Mansion House is the official residence of the Lord Mayor
St. Dunstan is a historical figure known for his legendary battle with the Evil Spirit
The Evil Spirit is a mythical figure who is said to have been defeated by St. Dunstan
A Christmas carol is a song sung during the Christmas season to spread cheer and goodwill A song sung by a boy at Scrooge's door the previous night
The poor and destitute individuals who suffer greatly and are in need of common necessities and comforts
Labourers who are repairing gas-pipes and warming themselves by a fire in the street
A group of impoverished individuals gathered around a fire to keep warm
A tailor who was fined by the Lord Mayor and is preparing for Christmas with his family
The wife of the little tailor, who is described as lean and is preparing for Christmas
The baby of the little tailor and his lean wife, who is part of the family preparing for Christmas

An ancient tower of a church with a gruff old bell that strikes the hours and quarters
The church is a place where people flock to in their best clothes and with their gayest faces The place where Bob Cratchit and Tiny Tim went before returning home.
The main street where labourers are repairing gas-pipes and people are warming themselves by a fire
The gas-pipes being repaired by labourers in the main street
A water-plug left in solitude, whose overflowings have turned to ice
Shops with bright windows displaying holly sprigs and berries, making faces ruddy as people pass by
Shops that are part of a splendid joke and a glorious pageant during the Christmas season
The City of London is the location where Scrooge resides and works
Camden Town is where Bob Cratchit runs home to play blind man's-buff Camden Town is the location to which Scrooge plans to send the turkey
Marley's face appearing on the knocker is a supernatural event that startles Scrooge
The Dutch merchant is the person who built the old fireplace in Scrooge's house
Figures depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
Figures depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
Figures depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
Figures depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
Figures depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
Figures depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
The wine-merchant owns the cellar below Scrooge's house
A legislative act mentioned in a metaphor about the width of Scrooge's staircase
A vehicle for carrying a coffin, which Scrooge imagines going up his staircase
Street lamps mentioned in the context of the darkness in Scrooge's house
Religious texts depicted on the Dutch tiles in Scrooge's fireplace
A biblical reference used to describe Marley's face overshadowing other thoughts
Supernatural beings described as dragging chains in haunted houses
Houses believed to be inhabited by ghosts, mentioned in the context of Scrooge's experience

The supernatural occurrence of Marley's ghost appearing to Scrooge
A supernatural visitor that appears to Scrooge, described as a strange figure resembling both a child and an old man The Ghost is a supernatural being guiding Scrooge through his past memories The Ghost is a supernatural entity guiding Scrooge through his past experiences
The Ghost is a supernatural entity that guides Scrooge through his memories, prompting reflections and realizations The Ghost is a supernatural being showing Scrooge scenes from his past The Ghost is a supernatural entity that shows Scrooge visions of his past, present, and future The Ghost is a spirit who tells Scrooge about Tiny Tim's potential future The Ghost is a spirit who shows Scrooge visions of the future and rebukes him for his past behavior The Ghost is a spirit guiding Scrooge through different scenes, spreading mirth and joy The Ghost is a spirit accompanying Scrooge and showing him various scenes

Jacob Marley is a ghost who was once a business partner of Ebenezer Scrooge and now suffers in the afterlife for his earthly misdeeds Jacob Marley is a ghost who appears to Scrooge to warn him about his fate and the visits of three spirits Jacob Marley is a deceased partner of Scrooge who sends supernatural messengers to him Jacob Marley is a deceased character whose memory haunts Scrooge, reminding him of his past The ghost of Scrooge's former business partner who predicted the arrival of the spirits Jacob Marley is the ghost of Scrooge's former business partner who warns him of the impending visits by spirits

The Phantom is another term used to describe the Ghost that visits Scrooge Another name for the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come The Phantom is a spirit guiding Scrooge through various scenes The Phantom is a ghostly figure accompanying Scrooge The Phantom is a ghostly figure that Scrooge glances towards The Phantom is a ghostly figure pointing towards the head of a dead man, guiding Scrooge through a fearful experience
The world is referenced as the place where spirits wander after death if they did not do so in life
The Ward is mentioned as a figure who would have been justified in indicting the Ghost for making noise
Jacob is a ghost who appears to Scrooge to warn him about his fate and the visits of three spirits Jacob is Scrooge's old partner whose death is mentioned
The Three Spirits are supernatural entities that will visit Scrooge to offer him a chance to change his fate
Phantoms are spirits seen by Scrooge, wandering in the air, wearing chains, and lamenting their inability to interfere in human matters
A church near Scrooge's residence whose chimes are heard by Scrooge
The event warned by Marley's Ghost, where Scrooge is to be visited by another ghost when the bell tolls one

A supernatural entity that appears to Scrooge, described as a strange figure resembling both a child and an old man Another term used to refer to the Ghost guiding Scrooge
The Spirit is a supernatural entity that guides Scrooge and teaches him lessons The Spirit is a supernatural being who accompanies Scrooge and has the ability to sprinkle incense from his torch to restore good humor The Spirit is another term used for the Ghost guiding Scrooge
A ghostly figure that shows Scrooge visions of the future and warns him about Ignorance and Want The Spirit is another term used to refer to the Phantom guiding Scrooge
The Spirit is another term used for the Ghost guiding Scrooge
A financial document mentioned by Scrooge, indicating a payment to be made to him
An open country road with fields on either side where Scrooge and the Ghost of Christmas Past stand
The period in Scrooge's life that the Ghost of Christmas Past is showing him
Ali Baba is a character from Arabian Nights, whom Scrooge recalls fondly from his childhood imagination
Valentine is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, mentioned alongside his wild brother Orson
Orson is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, mentioned alongside his brother Valentine
Damascus is a city mentioned in Scrooge's recollection of a story involving a character put down in his drawers at its gate
The Sultan's Groom is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, turned upside down by the Genii
The Genii are supernatural beings from Scrooge's childhood imagination, responsible for turning the Sultan's Groom upside down
The Princess is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, mentioned in relation to the Sultan's Groom
The Parrot is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, associated with Robin Crusoe
Robin Crusoe is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, likely a reference to Robinson Crusoe
Friday is a character from Scrooge's childhood imagination, likely a reference to Robinson Crusoe's companion
The main road that Scrooge and the Ghost leave to approach the mansion
A well-remembered lane that Scrooge and the Ghost travel down to reach the mansion
Part of the mansion's grounds, where fowls cluck and strut
Part of the mansion's grounds, overrun with grass
Part of the mansion's grounds, overrun with grass
The dreary hall inside the mansion that Scrooge and the Ghost cross

A long, bare, melancholy room in the mansion where Scrooge sees his younger self The room is the setting where the matron and her children are gathered The room where the dead man lies and where Scrooge and the Phantom are present
An empty storehouse with an idle swinging door in the mansion's yard
The dull yard behind the mansion
A despondent poplar tree in the mansion's yard
A lonely boy reading near a feeble fire, representing Scrooge's younger self
The schoolmaster is a figure from Scrooge's past who interacts with him and his sister

The place where Scrooge was apprenticed and where Fezziwig worked The warehouse is the place of business where Fezziwig, Ebenezer, and Dick Wilkins work and where the Christmas Eve celebration takes place
Ebenezer is a former apprentice of Fezziwig, now grown into a young man, who is very much attached to his fellow apprentice, Dick Wilkins
The three Miss Fezziwigs are the daughters of Old Fezziwig, known for their beaming and lovable nature
Country that negotiated a swap of money in exchange for hostages
Capital of Firuzabad where the Aurelians were being held
Aurelian who spent time in Tiruzia's Alhamia Prison
Aurelian journalist who was held hostage
Bratinas national and environmentalist who was held hostage
Dick is one of the apprentices who praises Fezziwig and is part of Scrooge's past memories
The fair young girl is a character who speaks to Scrooge about how his pursuit of wealth has displaced her in his affections
The domestic ball is an event hosted by Fezziwig where guests dance and celebrate, ending at eleven o'clock
The girl is a character who was once in a relationship with Scrooge and is now a comely matron The girl who answers the door at Fred's house and shows Scrooge upstairs
The matron is the same girl from Scrooge's past, now grown and with children

The children are the offspring of the matron, creating a tumultuous and lively scene The children are characters who excitedly greet their father and interact with the Christmas toys and presents The children of the mother, who are playing and whose voices she can hardly bear The children of Bob Cratchit and Mrs. Cratchit, including Peter and Tiny Tim
The winter fire is a comforting element in the scene with the matron and her children
The mother is a character who sits with her husband and daughter by the fireside A mother who is anxiously waiting for someone and is revealed by the Phantom to Scrooge
The second spirit is a supernatural entity that visits Scrooge after the first spirit
The parlour is a room in the house where the children and their emotions are described The space behind the screen of rags in Old Joe's shop where the characters gather
The office is the place where Scrooge is seen by Belle's husband
The bedroom is where Scrooge finds himself after his encounter with the Ghost
The fireside is where the master of the house sits with his daughter and wife
Mistletoe is a type of plant with crisp leaves that reflect light, used as decoration in the room where the Ghost of Christmas Present appears
Ivy is a type of plant with crisp leaves that reflect light, used as decoration in the room where the Ghost of Christmas Present appears
Plenty's Horn is a symbolic reference to abundance, represented by the glowing torch held by the Ghost of Christmas Present
Great Britain is the country where the events are taking place, characterized by a gloomy climate and town
The people in the city are shoveling snow and engaging in festive activities on Christmas morning
The house-tops are where people are shoveling snow and engaging in jovial activities
The Grocer's is a shop nearly closed on Christmas morning, filled with various goods and festive items
The Poulterer's is a shop that is half open on Christmas morning, selling poultry and other goods
The Fruiterer's is a shop that is radiant with fruits and other goods on Christmas morning

Christmas Day is the occasion being celebrated, during which people are seen carrying their dinners to the bakers' shops Christmas Day is the day on which the events in the Cratchit household take place. It is a significant day for the family, filled with joy, surprises, and a festive meal.
Christmas Day is the holiday that Scrooge wakes up to after his transformative experience with the spirits Christmas Day is the holiday being celebrated, which is central to the events in the text
The chapel is another place where people flock to in their best clothes and with their gayest faces
The baker is a character who shuts up his shop after the bells cease, and the progress of the dinners' cooking is seen in the thawed blotch of wet above each baker's oven
Bob Cratchit's dwelling is a modest four-roomed house that the Spirit blesses with the sprinklings of his torch
Master Peter Cratchit is the son and heir of Bob Cratchit. He is described as wearing a monstrous shirt-collar and is eager to show off his attire. He helps with the meal by mashing the potatoes.

Tiny Tim is the youngest son of Bob Cratchit. He is a cripple who uses a little crutch and has his limbs supported by an iron frame. Despite his condition, he is thoughtful and hopeful, wishing to inspire others. Tiny Tim is a young member of the Cratchit family who is frail and sits beside his father, Bob Cratchit Tiny Tim is a child who is ill and whose future is uncertain Tiny Tim is the deceased child of Bob Cratchit and Mrs. Cratchit Tiny Tim is a child who is remembered fondly by Bob and his family Tiny Tim is Bob Cratchit's son, who is mentioned in comparison to the size of the turkey Tiny Tim is a young boy who is part of Bob Cratchit's family and is shown to be alive and well after Scrooge's transformation
The place where Tiny Tim was taken by his siblings to hear the pudding singing in the copper.
Master Peter is a member of the Cratchit family who mashed the potatoes with incredible vigor
Miss Belinda is a member of the Cratchit family who sweetened the apple sauce and changed the plates
Martha is a member of the Cratchit family who dusted the hot plates
The dinner is the meal prepared and enjoyed by the Cratchit family, featuring a goose and pudding
A title given to Scrooge by Bob Cratchit, albeit sarcastically
Miners are people who live on a bleak and desert moor and are seen celebrating Christmas in a hut
A solitary lighthouse built on a dismal reef of sunken rocks, where two men are celebrating Christmas
A ship far away from any shore, where the crew is celebrating Christmas
A hut on the bleak and desert moor where miners and their families are celebrating Christmas
The sea that Scrooge and the Ghost travel over, encountering a lighthouse and a ship
An old man in the hut who sings a Christmas song to his family
A lamplighter who laughs as the Spirit passes by
Two men who watch the light in the lighthouse and celebrate Christmas
The crew of the ship who celebrate Christmas

Scrooge's niece is described as exceedingly pretty, earnest, and opinionated, particularly about Scrooge's wealth and behavior Scrooge's niece is a musical character who plays the harp and participates in the games

Topper is a character who is a bachelor and has his eye on one of Scrooge's niece's sisters Topper is a character who is part of the musical family and participates in the games, particularly blind man's-buff Topper is a character who could have told you about the sharp girls at the gathering Topper is a guest at Fred's dinner party
Scrooge's niece's sister is the plump one with the lace tucker who blushes when Topper expresses his opinion
The plump sister is a character who participates in the games and is often pursued by Topper during blind man's-buff The plump sister is another guest at Fred's dinner party
London is the city where the story takes place and where the animal in the guessing game lives
A children's party that Scrooge and the Spirit visited during their travels
The Christmas holidays are the time period during which Scrooge and the Spirit travel together
An almshouse is one of the places visited by the Spirit and Scrooge, where they observed cheerfulness despite poverty
A hospital is one of the places visited by the Spirit and Scrooge, where they observed cheerfulness despite illness
A gaol (jail) is one of the places visited by the Spirit and Scrooge, where they observed cheerfulness despite imprisonment
A boy representing ignorance, shown to Scrooge by the Spirit
A girl representing want, shown to Scrooge by the Spirit
The ghost of Scrooge's former business partner who predicted the arrival of the spirits
The location in the city where merchants gather Change is a location within the City where merchants gather
Business men are wealthy and important individuals in the City who discuss the death of an unknown person
A red-faced gentleman with a pendulous excrescence on his nose who discusses the death of an unknown person
A great fat man with a monstrous chin who discusses the death of an unknown person
Old Scratch is a colloquial term used to refer to the Devil, mentioned by the business men
Old Joe is a grey-haired rascal who owns a shop dealing in second-hand goods
The laundress is a woman who enters Old Joe's shop with a heavy bundle
The undertaker's man is a man in faded black who enters Old Joe's shop
An obscure part of the town with a bad reputation where Scrooge and the Phantom visit The town where Scrooge asks the Spirit to show him someone who feels emotion caused by the man's death
A low-browed, beetling shop owned by Old Joe where second-hand goods are bought and sold
An infamous part of the town known for its bad reputation, where Old Joe's shop is located
The deceased man whose belongings are being plundered and discussed by Joe and the others
The event of a man's death, which is causing various emotions and reactions among the characters
Caroline's husband is a young man with a careworn and depressed face, who brings the news of the creditor's death
A merciless creditor whose death brings relief to Caroline and her husband The merciless creditor whose death brings relief to Caroline and her family
The dark, empty house where the dead man lies
The bed on which the dead man lies
The location beneath which rats are gnawing in the room of death
The door that the cat is tearing at in the room of death
The window from which the mother looks out anxiously
The clock that the mother glances at while waiting
Peter is one of the Cratchit children Peter is a character who interacts with Bob and is mentioned in relation to getting a better situation
Mr. Scrooge's nephew is a kind gentleman who offers help to Bob Cratchit
The house where Bob Cratchit and his family live
The place around which the Cratchit family gathers
The book that Peter is reading
The entrance to Bob Cratchit's house
The chair set close beside Tiny Tim's body
The place where Bob Cratchit's tea is kept warm
The street where Mr. Scrooge's nephew meets Bob Cratchit
The day Bob Cratchit promises to visit Tiny Tim's grave
Bob is a character who speaks about his good wife and Tiny Tim
A place where Scrooge sees the grave with his name on it
The place where Scrooge works and sees a different figure in the chair
The gate that Scrooge and the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come pass through before entering the churchyard
The Ghost of Christmas Future, also known as the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come, shows Scrooge the potential future consequences of his actions
The Past is one of the time periods that Scrooge vows to honor and learn from after his transformative experience
The Present is one of the time periods that Scrooge vows to honor and learn from after his transformative experience
The Future is one of the time periods that Scrooge vows to honor and learn from after his transformative experience
The portly gentleman is a character who had previously visited Scrooge's counting-house to ask for donations
The lad is the boy who Scrooge asks to buy the turkey and bring it to him
Joe Miller is mentioned in comparison to the joke of sending the turkey to Bob Cratchit
Fred's wife, who is surprised by Scrooge's arrival at the dinner party
Fred's wife, who is in the dining room when Scrooge arrives
Illustration is a visual representation included in the text to depict scenes from the story

Philadelphia is one of the cities where "A Christmas Carol" was originally published
New York is one of the cities where "A Christmas Carol" was originally published
Marley's Ghost is the first chapter of "A Christmas Carol"

edge.target: THE FIRST OF THE THREE SPIRITS
edge.data: The First of the Three Spirits is the second chapter of "A Christmas Carol"

edge.target: THE SECOND OF THE THREE SPIRITS
edge.data: The Second of the Three Spirits is the third chapter of "A Christmas Carol"
The Last of the Spirits is the fourth chapter of "A Christmas Carol"
The End of It is the fifth and final chapter of "A Christmas Carol"
Bob Cratchit is the clerk to Ebenezer Scrooge in "A Christmas Carol"
Peter Cratchit is the son of Bob Cratchit in "A Christmas Carol" Peter Cratchit is Bob Cratchit's son
Tim Cratchit, also known as Tiny Tim, is the youngest son of Bob Cratchit in "A Christmas Carol"

Mrs. Cratchit is the wife of Bob Cratchit in "A Christmas Carol" Mrs. Cratchit is Bob Cratchit's wife Bob Cratchit and Mrs. Cratchit are husband and wife, working together to support their family. Mrs. Cratchit and Bob Cratchit are married and part of the Cratchit family Bob Cratchit is married to Mrs. Cratchit
Belinda Cratchit is a daughter of Bob Cratchit in "A Christmas Carol"
Martha Cratchit is a daughter of Bob Cratchit in "A Christmas Carol" Martha Cratchit is Bob Cratchit's daughter

Scrooge is Bob Cratchit's employer and is reluctant to give him a day off on Christmas Eve Bob Cratchit is Scrooge's clerk Bob Cratchit works for Scrooge Scrooge is observing Bob Cratchit's family Scrooge plans to send a large turkey to Bob Cratchit as a surprise gift Scrooge is Bob Cratchit's employer and decides to raise his salary and assist his family Scrooge promises to raise Bob Cratchit's salary and assist his struggling family
Bob Cratchit runs home to Camden Town to play blind man's-buff
Bob Cratchit celebrates Christmas Eve by sliding on Cornhill and running home
Bob Cratchit slides on Cornhill in celebration of Christmas Eve
The Spirit blesses Bob Cratchit's house with the sprinklings of his torch
The Ghost of Christmas Present blesses Bob Cratchit's house The Ghost of Christmas Present blesses Bob Cratchit's house, showing a supernatural connection to the Cratchit family.
Bob Cratchit lives in a modest four-roomed house

Bob Cratchit is the father of Tiny Tim and is very caring towards him, carrying him on his shoulder and being concerned about his health. Bob Cratchit is Tiny Tim's father and shows great affection and concern for him Tiny Tim is Bob Cratchit's son Bob Cratchit is the father of Tiny Tim
Christmas Day is significant for Bob Cratchit as it is the day he spends with his family, filled with joy and celebration. Bob Cratchit celebrates Christmas Day with his family
Bob Cratchit lives in the Cratchit dwelling with his family.
Bob Cratchit took Tiny Tim to the church before returning home.
Bob Cratchit is a member of the Cratchit family
Bob Cratchit is celebrating Christmas with his family The events are taking place during Christmas
Bob Cratchit is participating in the family dinner
Bob Cratchit is the father of Peter
Mr. Scrooge's nephew offers help to Bob Cratchit
Bob Cratchit lives in this house with his family
Bob Cratchit is the father of the children
The Cratchit family gathers around the fire
Bob Cratchit sits in the chair beside Tiny Tim's body
Bob Cratchit's tea is kept warm on the hob
Bob Cratchit meets Mr. Scrooge's nephew in the street
Bob Cratchit promises to visit Tiny Tim's grave on Sunday
Fred is the nephew of Ebenezer Scrooge in "A Christmas Carol"
The Ghost of Jacob Marley is the spectre of Scrooge's former partner in business in "A Christmas Carol"
Fan is the sister of Scrooge in "A Christmas Carol"
Jacob Marley, as a ghost, visits Ebenezer Scrooge to warn him about the consequences of his actions Jacob Marley appears to Scrooge to warn him about his fate and the visits of three spirits
The Ghost visits Ebenezer Scrooge to warn him about the consequences of his actions The Ghost appears to Scrooge and is described in detail
The Phantom, another term for the Ghost, interacts with Ebenezer Scrooge
The counting-house is where Scrooge and Jacob Marley conducted their business
Marley's Ghost is the apparition of Jacob Marley, who warns Scrooge about his fate and the visits of three spirits Marley's Ghost haunts Scrooge and warns him of future visitations
The Three Spirits will visit Scrooge to offer him a chance to change his fate

edge.target: THE FIRST OF THE THREE SPIRITS
edge.data: The First of the Three Spirits will visit Scrooge
Scrooge is warned by Marley's Ghost about a visitation
Scrooge hears the chimes of the neighbouring church
Scrooge hears the chimes of the neighbouring church
The Spirit appears to Scrooge and is described in detail
Scrooge mentions the First of Exchange as a financial document
Scrooge reads his own name, Ebenezer Scrooge, on a neglected grave
Peter Cratchit celebrates Christmas Day with his family
Mrs. Fezziwig is the worthy partner of Mr. Fezziwig in "A Christmas Carol" Mr. Fezziwig and Mrs. Fezziwig are partners in dancing and hosts of the domestic ball
Mr. Fezziwig hosts the domestic ball, spreading cheer among the guests

Fred invited his uncle Scrooge to dinner Fred is Scrooge's nephew and expresses sympathy for him despite his unpleasant nature Fred is Scrooge's nephew and hosted the game where Scrooge was the subject Scrooge is Fred's uncle and is warmly welcomed to dinner
Uncle Scrooge is invited to dinner by Fred
Fred enjoys Christmas and finds it a time for laughter and good-humor
Topper is a guest at Fred's dinner party
The plump sister is a guest at Fred's dinner party

The Ghost of Christmas Past visits Scrooge to show him scenes from his past for his reclamation The Ghost of Christmas Past guides Scrooge through his memories The Ghost of Christmas Past shows Scrooge scenes from his past The Ghost of Christmas Past shows Scrooge scenes from his past The Ghost of Christmas Past shows Scrooge scenes from his past
The Ghost of Christmas Past is associated with the period of Christmas Past

The Ghost of Christmas Present appears to Scrooge to show him the spirit of the holiday Scrooge is guided by the Ghost of Christmas Present The Ghost of Christmas Present shows Scrooge scenes from the present The Ghost of Christmas Present shows Scrooge the current state of affairs and introduces him to Ignorance and Want The Ghost of Christmas Present shows Scrooge the current state of his life and the lives of others Scrooge recalls seeing people with the Ghost of Christmas Present
The Ghost of Christmas Present embodies the spirit of the Christmas holiday
Holly is part of the festive decorations surrounding the Ghost of Christmas Present
Mistletoe is part of the festive decorations surrounding the Ghost of Christmas Present
Ivy is part of the festive decorations surrounding the Ghost of Christmas Present
The Ghost of Christmas Present holds a glowing torch shaped like Plenty's Horn
The Ghost of Christmas Present is a specific form of the Spirit The Spirit is also referred to as the Ghost of Christmas Present
The Ghost of Christmas Present is associated with Christmas Day, spreading joy and blessings.

edge.source: GHOST OF CHRISTMAS YET TO COME
edge.data: The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come shows Scrooge the future Scrooge is shown visions of the future by the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come shows Scrooge the potential future consequences of his actions
The Ghost of Jacob Marley warns Scrooge about the visits from the three spirits
Joe discussed bed-curtains with a woman, which is related to Scrooge's story
Joe appraises and buys items brought by Mrs. Dilber
Joe appraises and buys items brought by the woman
Joe appraises and buys items that were taken from the unhappy man
Fezziwig is the former employer of Dick Wilkins, and they share a warm relationship, especially evident during the Christmas Eve celebration
Ebenezer and Dick Wilkins were fellow apprentices and shared a close bond
Dick Wilkins works at the warehouse and participates in the Christmas Eve celebration
Belle is an old friend of Scrooge, and her husband mentions seeing Scrooge
Belle is the wife of the father
Belle sits with her husband and mother by the fireside
Caroline and her husband discuss the death of the creditor and its implications
Caroline feels relief upon hearing about the death of the merciless creditor Caroline feels relief at the death of the merciless creditor
Caroline and her husband live in the town where the creditor's death has an impact
Mrs. Cratchit and Belinda Cratchit are mother and daughter, working together to prepare the family meal.
Mrs. Cratchit and Master Peter Cratchit are mother and son, with Peter helping in the kitchen by mashing the potatoes.
Mrs. Cratchit and Martha Cratchit are mother and daughter, with Mrs. Cratchit warmly welcoming Martha when she arrives home.
Mrs. Cratchit lives in the Cratchit dwelling with her family.
Master Peter is a member of the Cratchit family and helps with the dinner preparations
Miss Belinda is a member of the Cratchit family and helps with the dinner preparations
Martha is a member of the Cratchit family and helps with the dinner preparations
Tiny Tim is a member of the Cratchit family and part of the dinner scene Mrs. Cratchit is the mother of Tiny Tim
Mrs. Cratchit is a member of the Cratchit family
Mrs. Cratchit is celebrating Christmas with her family
Mrs. Cratchit is participating in the family dinner
Mrs. Cratchit celebrates Christmas Day with her family
Mrs. Cratchit is the mother of Peter Mrs. Cratchit speaks to Peter about his future
Mrs. Cratchit is the mother of the children
Bob and Mrs. Cratchit are married and interact with each otherMrs. Cratchit is Bob's wife and interacts with him
Belinda Cratchit lives in the Cratchit dwelling with her family.
Martha Cratchit and Tiny Tim are siblings, with Martha hiding to surprise her father and being part of the family celebration.
Martha Cratchit lives in the Cratchit dwelling with her family.
Martha Cratchit celebrates Christmas Day with her family
Mrs. Dilber interacts with Old Joe in his shop
Mrs. Dilber and the laundress meet in Old Joe's shop
Mrs. Dilber and the undertaker's man meet in Old Joe's shop
The charwoman and Mrs. Dilber meet in Old Joe's shop
Fan is Scrooge's sister who comes to bring him home for Christmas
Fan brings Scrooge home for Christmas

Old Fezziwig and Mrs. Fezziwig danced together Fezziwig and Mrs. Fezziwig are married and both participate in the Christmas Eve festivities Fezziwig and Mrs. Fezziwig are partners in dancing and hosts of the domestic ball
Mrs. Fezziwig participates in the Christmas Eve celebration hosted by Fezziwig
Mrs. Fezziwig participates in the Christmas Eve celebration at the warehouse

edge.source: THE FIRST OF THE THREE SPIRITS
edge.data: The First of the Three Spirits will visit Scrooge

Marley's Ghost is an event that involves Scrooge Scrooge is confronted by the ghost of Marley, which he initially disbelieves Marley's Ghost is the apparition of Jacob Marley, who warns Scrooge about his fate and the visits of three spirits
Marley's Ghost informs Scrooge about the visits of the Three Spirits
Fezziwig was Scrooge's employer during his apprenticeship
Fezziwig worked at the warehouse where Scrooge was apprenticed Fezziwig runs the warehouse where the Christmas Eve celebration takes place
Fezziwig is the former employer of Ebenezer, and they share a warm relationship, especially evident during the Christmas Eve celebration
Fezziwig is the father of the three Miss Fezziwigs, who are known for their beaming and lovable nature
Fezziwig hosts a lively and generous celebration on Christmas Eve
Scrooge speaks to the Ghost about Fezziwig, showing his fond memories of his former employer
Fezziwig hosts the domestic ball, spreading cheer among the guests

Scrooge and Marley were business partners, and Scrooge was Marley's sole executor Marley was Scrooge's business partner who has been dead for seven years Marley was Scrooge's deceased partner whose face appears on the knocker Scrooge is haunted by the memory and face of Marley, who has been dead for seven years Marley was Scrooge's business partner in life and now appears to him as a ghost Marley is mentioned in relation to Scrooge, indicating a past connection
Tim is mentioned in the context of Scrooge's story
Old Scratch is mentioned in a conversation related to Scrooge
Scrooge attended Marley's Funeral and was his sole executor

Scrooge's nephew tries to engage with Scrooge and spread Christmas cheer, despite Scrooge's negative attitude towards Christmas Scrooge's nephew is related to Scrooge and expresses sympathy for him despite his unpleasant nature Scrooge's nephew tries to include Scrooge in Christmas celebrations despite Scrooge's dislike for the holiday Scrooge's nephew hosted the game and led the toast to Scrooge
Scrooge works in the counting-house, which reflects his cold and unfeeling nature
Scrooge is busy working in his counting-house on Christmas Eve, showing his disregard for the holiday Scrooge is reluctant to give Bob Cratchit a day off on Christmas Eve
The clerk works for Scrooge and suffers from the cold environment in the counting-house The clerk works for Scrooge and shares the nephew's positive views on Christmas

Scrooge lives and works in the city, which is described as cold, bleak, and foggy Scrooge's business friends in the City would be surprised to see his emotional state Scrooge and the Ghost observe the bustling activities in the city during Christmas Scrooge and the Spirit find themselves in the heart of the City Scrooge and the Phantom are in the City Scrooge becomes known as a good man in the city
The neighbouring offices are near Scrooge's counting-house, and their candles are visible through the fog
The court is outside Scrooge's counting-house, where people are trying to warm themselves
Scrooge is the uncle of the nephew, and they have differing views on Christmas Scrooge's nephew is the child of his sister Fan Scrooge is welcomed by his nephew Fred to the dinner party
Scrooge is the surviving partner of the business Scrooge and Marley Scrooge works at Scrooge and Marley, the counting-house
The portly gentlemen visit Scrooge to seek donations for charity

Scrooge is cynical about Christmas and expresses his disdain for it Scrooge is notably uncharitable during the Christmas season Scrooge has complex emotions and memories associated with Christmas Many of Scrooge's past experiences and reflections are centered around Christmas Scrooge's reflections and interactions with the Ghost take place during Christmas The events and reflections of Scrooge take place during Christmas Scrooge is experiencing supernatural events related to the Christmas holiday Scrooge's experiences and lessons are centered around the Christmas holiday Scrooge has a negative opinion about Christmas, calling it a humbug Scrooge has a complex relationship with Christmas, initially disliking it but gradually softening Scrooge is observing events during Christmas Scrooge learns to keep Christmas well and becomes generous
Scrooge supports the Union workhouses as a means to provide for the poor
Scrooge mentions the Treadmill as a form of punishment and labor for the poor
Scrooge references the Poor Law as a means to support the poor
Scrooge reacts negatively to a Christmas carol sung at his keyhole Scrooge recalls a boy singing a Christmas carol at his door
The gentleman approaches Scrooge to ask for donations for the poor Scrooge interacts with the gentleman and surprises him with his generosity
The church's bell strikes the hours and quarters, which Scrooge can hear
Scrooge lives and works in the City of London
Scrooge is startled by the appearance of Marley's face on the knocker
The Dutch merchant built the old fireplace in Scrooge's house
The wine-merchant owns the cellar below Scrooge's house, where strange noises are heard
Scrooge imagines a hearse going up his staircase
Scrooge hears noises that he associates with ghosts dragging chains
Scrooge's house is described with elements typical of haunted houses

Jacob Marley was Scrooge's business partner in life and now appears to him as a ghost Jacob Marley sends supernatural messengers to Scrooge Jacob Marley's memory haunts Scrooge, reminding him of his past Jacob Marley predicted the arrival of the spirits to Scrooge Jacob Marley is the ghost who warns Scrooge about the visits from the three spirits

Scrooge is confronted by the ghost of Jacob Marley, which he initially disbelieves The Ghost is guiding Scrooge through his past memories The Ghost is guiding Scrooge through his past experiences Scrooge interacts with the Ghost, reflecting on his past and experiencing a range of emotions The Ghost is showing Scrooge scenes from his past to reflect on his life choices The Ghost shows Scrooge visions of his life and influences his reflections Scrooge speaks with the Ghost about Tiny Tim's future The Ghost shows Scrooge visions of the future and rebukes him The Ghost is guiding Scrooge through various scenes of Christmas celebrations The Ghost is accompanying Scrooge and showing him various scenes The Ghost is guiding Scrooge through various scenes
Jacob appears to Scrooge to warn him about his fate and the visits of three spirits Jacob was Scrooge's old partner
The Three Spirits will visit Scrooge to offer him a chance to change his fate
Scrooge sees phantoms wandering in the air, lamenting their inability to interfere in human matters
Scrooge recognizes the market-town from his past
Scrooge and the Ghost of Christmas Past stand on the country road
The Ghost of Christmas Past shows Scrooge scenes from his past
Scrooge recalls Ali Baba fondly from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls Valentine from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls Orson from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls a story involving a character at the gate of Damascus
Scrooge recalls the Sultan's Groom from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls the Genii from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls the Parrot from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls Robin Crusoe from his childhood imagination
Scrooge recalls Friday from his childhood imagination

Scrooge and the Ghost leave the high-road to approach the mansion
Scrooge and the Ghost travel down a well-remembered lane to reach the mansion

The Spirit is guiding Scrooge through his past memories The Spirit is showing Scrooge scenes from his past to reflect on his life choices Scrooge interacts with the Spirit to learn lessons Scrooge interacts with the Spirit, questioning him about his actions and intentions The Spirit is guiding Scrooge through various scenes of Christmas celebrations The Spirit is accompanying Scrooge and showing him various scenes The Spirit shows Scrooge visions of the future and warns him about Ignorance and Want The Spirit is guiding Scrooge through various scenes Scrooge interacts with the Spirit, asking it to show him someone who feels emotion caused by the man's death The Spirit is guiding Scrooge through various scenes Scrooge interacts with the Spirit, pleading for a chance to change his ways
The boy represents Scrooge's younger self
The schoolmaster interacts with Scrooge and his sister during their childhood
Scrooge was apprenticed at the warehouse where Fezziwig worked
Scrooge remembers his past with Dick, one of the apprentices
The fair young girl speaks to Scrooge about how his pursuit of wealth has displaced her
The girl was once in a relationship with Scrooge, which ended due to his pursuit of wealth Scrooge asks the girl if her master is at home and she shows him upstairs
Scrooge is seen by Belle's husband in his office
Scrooge finds himself in his bedroom after his encounter with the Ghost
The second spirit visits Scrooge after the first spirit
Scrooge and the Spirit stand in the city streets on Christmas morning

Scrooge observes the events and interactions on Christmas Day Scrooge is the subject of a toast on Christmas Day Scrooge wakes up on Christmas Day after his transformative experience with the spirits Scrooge is experiencing a transformation in his attitude and actions on Christmas Day

Scrooge shows concern for Tiny Tim's future and asks the Ghost about it Scrooge is concerned about Tiny Tim's health Scrooge compares the size of the turkey to Tiny Tim Scrooge becomes a second father to Tiny Tim and ensures his well-being
Scrooge is referred to as the Founder of the Feast by Bob Cratchit
Scrooge's niece is related to Scrooge and has strong opinions about his wealth and behavior
Scrooge lives in London, which is also where the animal in the guessing game lives
Scrooge and the Spirit visited a children's Twelfth-Night party
Scrooge and the Spirit traveled together during the Christmas holidays
Scrooge and the Spirit visited an almshouse where they observed cheerfulness despite poverty
Scrooge and the Spirit visited a hospital where they observed cheerfulness despite illness
Scrooge and the Spirit visited a gaol where they observed cheerfulness despite imprisonment
Old Jacob Marley predicted the arrival of the spirits to Scrooge

The Phantom, also known as the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come, shows Scrooge the future The Phantom is guiding Scrooge through various scenes Scrooge is accompanied by the Phantom Scrooge glances towards the Phantom in terror Scrooge is being guided by the Phantom through a fearful experience
Scrooge and the Phantom are in Change, a part of the City
Scrooge observes the merchants in the City
Scrooge listens to the business men discussing the death of an unknown person
Scrooge listens to the red-faced gentleman discussing the death of an unknown person
Scrooge listens to the great fat man discussing the death of an unknown person

Scrooge visits an infamous part of the town
Scrooge is horrified by the treatment of the unhappy man's belongings

Scrooge is in the dark, empty house where the dead man lies

Scrooge notices the cat tearing at the door in the room of death

Scrooge sees his office with a different figure in the chair

Scrooge vows to honor and learn from the Past
Scrooge vows to honor and learn from the Present
Scrooge vows to honor and learn from the Future
Scrooge plans to send the turkey to Camden Town
Scrooge meets the portly gentleman and offers a generous donation
Scrooge instructs the boy to buy the turkey from the poulterer
Scrooge asks the lad to buy the turkey and bring it to him
Scrooge compares the joke of sending the turkey to Bob Cratchit to a joke by Joe Miller
Scrooge surprises his niece by marriage with his arrival at the dinner party
Scrooge asks the girl about the mistress, who is in the dining room
Marley's face is described as overshadowing other thoughts like the ancient Prophet's rod
Scrooge's nephew and niece are married and share opinions about Scrooge Scrooge's niece is part of the family and participates in the games, bringing joy to Scrooge's nephew
Jacob Marley's spirit never roved beyond the counting-house in life
Jacob Marley died seven years ago on Christmas Eve
The three Miss Fezziwigs participate in the Christmas Eve celebration hosted by Fezziwig
The Christmas Eve celebration takes place at the warehouse
The city is bustling with activities during Christmas
Change is a location within the city where merchants gather
Labourers are working at the corner of the court
The clerk shares the nephew's positive views on Christmas
The nephew values Christmas and believes it has done him good
Fred's wife is his niece by marriage
The Ghost shows Scrooge past Christmas events The Ghost is spreading mirth and joy during Christmas
The events and festive activities are taking place in Great Britain during Christmas
The Grocer's is nearly closed but filled with festive items on Christmas morning
The Poulterer's is half open and selling goods on Christmas morning
The Fruiterer's is radiant with fruits and other goods on Christmas morning
Master Peter is celebrating Christmas with his family
Miss Belinda is celebrating Christmas with her family
Martha is celebrating Christmas with her family
Tiny Tim is celebrating Christmas with his family
The Cratchit family is celebrating Christmas
The dinner is part of the Cratchit family's Christmas celebration
The miners are celebrating Christmas in their hut
Two men in the lighthouse are celebrating Christmas
The crew on the ship is celebrating Christmas
The Spirit is spreading mirth and joy during Christmas
The old man is singing a Christmas song to his family
The lamplighter laughs as the Spirit passes by, indicating the joy of Christmas
The two men in the lighthouse celebrate Christmas by making a fire and singing
